Playing sports with a pump

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

â01-20-2012 02:18 PM

I was just diagnosed 3 motnhs ago with Type 1 - they are wanting to put me on the pump - I just dont know - I am a college volleyball player and even though I can take th pump off - I land on my stomach diving for the ball all the time - I dont know what to do - next Fall is my Senior year and there are alot of expectations that my team has for me - I dont want to let them down - I just started working out again after being diagnosed and my blood sugar dropped after 15 minutes of running - I am very discouraged

â01-23-2012 02:02 AM

hamrick18 wrote:

I was just diagnosed 3 motnhs ago with Type 1 - they are wanting to put me on the pump - I just dont know - I am a college volleyball player and even though I can take th pump off - I land on my stomach diving for the ball all the time - I dont know what to do - next Fall is my Senior year and there are alot of expectations that my team has for me - I dont want to let them down - I just started working out again after being diagnosed and my blood sugar dropped after 15 minutes of running - I am very discouraged

Rick,

 

You might want to post your question in the Type 1 forum (linky is in my signature area below). This forum doesn't get much traffic.

 

I don't pump, but there are other places that you can put it. The pumpers can help you out with that. I only use the cgm.

 

Before you start playing, exercising, running, etc., you will need to have more carb grams, to help keep you from dropping. This is where a pump would be good for you, the pumpers can also explain how it would be beneficial for you.

 

Trisha - Type 1



Trisha

IDDM (Type 1 Autoimmune) 30+ many more years ~ Currently using MDI & Minimed CGM ~
Check out my diabetes blog!

All brittle means, is that one has great fluctuations, which is pretty much hallmark for Type 1's. Some more so than others. - me

First light brings a new day, new hope, new wisdom, and a chance to start fresh again. - me

If everyone were dealt the same amount of cards, there would be no challenges in life. Challenges are part of life's lessons, to teach us to grow in all aspects, and to learn what we need to learn, to make it in this world. Life was not meant to be fair. -me

"WE, the PEOPLE....."

~ New Type 1 Info ~ Insulin, Test Strips, Lancets, and other meds ~ Kidney Damage Info ~



*****************
Sidenote to new members....please put which type of diabetes you have, in your signature area. T1's and T2's cross post on these forums, and it is imperative that we all know which type one is. This is so that no misinformation is given to anyone. Type 1 and Type 2 are two totally absolute different diseases with different causes, thus making self-management very different. Thank you!, and welcome to the forums.
*****************

â02-17-2012 11:15 PM

I have a pump and i usally take it off during gym because i don't want to break it trust me i had my shirt pulled over it and i fell on the sidewalk and scratched the screen and i've bent up a couple of clips because they don't make them very well and i've had my friend tackle me while playing football and break a clip so i always take it off during gym and during my basketball games because they just won't stand up for a person as active as me but the pump is a good idea because u only have to take one shot every 3 days at least that is how it is for me and that shot is the insert for my pump and it's nice to not to have to take shot's all the time but there's a bad side to the pump you can take a shot any time and the pump if the insulin cartrige runs out your pretty much screwed and have to go home and do a whole pump change but i would recommend the pump and sorry for sounding like a doctor

â04-30-2012 07:03 PM

I have type 1 diabetes and have a pump, it is so much better than taking the shots. i have also found out that it helps regulate my blood sugars. my sugas were around 300 with out my pump  and they are now around 100s. 

      playing with a pump is very easy as long as you have a clip on it. i play basketball volley ball and a alot more sports. it is not hard playing with a pump, you dont even konw that you have it on when you are playing.

â05-16-2012 05:28 PM

hey im also a type 1 volleyball player, and i was told by my doctor that i have to take off the pump while i play volleyball. he told me that if i need to take insulin during a long volleyball tounrament then i can just take a shot of insulin instead and then after volleyball i can put the pump back on. maybe you can try this, and yess your blood sugar will drop with excerise i always try to have my blood sugar around 120 before i play volleyball. hopefully this helps! keep your head up girl!
